title: Diary_hanjiang
text:
Introduction
Hello! I’m HAN JIANG. I’m currently pursuing my graduate studies at the Centre for Advanced Spatial Analysis (CASA) at UCL, marking my first foray into postgraduate education. My journey at UCL has been enriching, having completed courses in the Foundations of Spatial Data Science, Geographic Information Systems, Urban Systems Theory, Science, and Quantitative Methods. I’m currently delving into Remote Sensing, Agent-Based Modeling (ABM), Data Science, and Building Spatial Applications with Big Data, which are broadening my perspective and skill set in the spatial sciences.
I graduated in 2023 with a Bachelor’s degree from a collaborative program between Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications and Queen Mary University of London in E-commerce Engineering with Law. My undergraduate studies encompassed a diverse array of subjects including Advanced Network Programming, Engineering Mathematics, Discrete Mathematics, Advanced Mathematics, Telecommunications Engineering, Web Front-end Design, Databases, and Macroeconomics.
My internship experiences have been equally diverse and enriching. In 2022, I interned at the Institute of Automation, Chinese Academy of Sciences, where I was involved in projects related to Monkey Behavior Image Recognition and Mouse Behavior Recording, focusing mainly on video data annotation and model testing. In 2023, I took up a community operations role at EasyTransfer, where my primary responsibility was addressing and resolving user product inquiries and issues.
On a lighter note, here’s a bit more about me beyond academics and work: I’m a Leo born in the 2000s with an ENTP personality type. My hobbies include visiting parks (easy to get tired), exploring museums (easy to get lost), enjoying a drink (easy to be drunk), indulging in gourmet food (on a budget), and watching musicals (even as I struggle with English). I’ve been trying to become a blogger, but I have very few followers. I love dogs, especially my HuanHuan, who is 10 years old now. I miss her so much.

title: 1  Week_1
text: 2 Week 1 - Introduction to Remote Sensing

title: 1  Week_1
text:
2.1 Lecture Content

2.1.1 Remote Sensing Definition:
NASA defines it as acquiring information from a distance, using sensors mounted on platforms like satellites, planes, drones, and phones.



Here is a video that introduce Remote Sensing.



2.1.2 Types of Sensors:
Passive sensors detect reflected energy from the sun, while active sensors emit electromagnetic waves and wait for the reflection.


2.1.3 Data Interaction and Scattering:
Interaction with Earth’s surface and atmospheric scattering (Rayleigh, Mie, Non-selective) affects the data.
The interaction of electromagnetic waves with Earth’s surface and atmosphere is fundamental to many processes, including climate regulation, weather patterns, and the global energy balance. Here are how EM waves interact with Specific Atmospheric Components:
-Water Vapor: Absorbs infrared and microwave radiation, playing a significant role in the Earth’s energy balance.
-Ozone: Absorbs most of the Sun’s harmful ultraviolet radiation, protecting living organisms.
-Aerosols and Particulates: Scatter and absorb sunlight, which can cool the surface or contribute to atmospheric warming, depending on their properties.

title: 1  Week_1
section: 2.2 Four Resolutions of Remotely Sensing Data
text:
2.2 Four Resolutions of Remotely Sensing Data

Spatial: Size of raster cells varies from 10cm to several kilometers.
Spectral: Number of bands recorded, influenced by atmospheric windows.
Temporal: Frequency of sensor revisits, affecting data freshness.
Radiometric: Sensor’s ability to differentiate small energy differences, measured in bit depth (e.g., 8-bit, 256 values).

title: 1  Week_1
text:
2.3 Practical Applications

2.3.1 Introduction to Tools:
1. Loading Landsat and Sentinel Data

Landsat and Sentinel are two different Earth observation satellite programs. The Landsat program is managed jointly by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and NASA and has been operational since 1972, making it the longest-running enterprise for acquisition of satellite imagery of Earth. The Sentinel program is part of the European Space Agency (ESA) and supports the European Union’s Copernicus program, providing a wide range of data for environmental and security monitoring.
Loading the data involves retrieving these satellites’ imagery from databases or storage services. This may include specifying certain criteria like specific dates, areas of interest, cloud cover percentage, etc., to filter the data.

2. Selecting Regions of Interest (ROIs)

Selecting Regions of Interest (ROIs) is the process of identifying areas for focused analysis within the vast amounts of remote sensing data. These areas might be selected based on specific geographic features, ecosystems, urban areas, etc.
ROIs can be selected by manually drawing polygons, entering geographic coordinates, or using existing geographic information data (like vector layers). This step is crucial to ensure that subsequent analyses are concentrated on relevant areas.

3. Plotting Spectral Signatures

Spectral signatures refer to the characteristic pattern of reflection or absorption of light at different wavelengths by objects or materials. In remote sensing, analyzing the spectral reflectance of different terrestrial materials (like vegetation, water bodies, soil, etc.) allows for their identification and classification.
Plotting spectral signatures involves graphically representing these spectral characteristics, typically showing wavelength (or bands) against reflectance values. This helps in understanding the spectral behavior of different materials, which is vital for applications like material classification, vegetation health analysis, etc.
Applications of Remote Sensing: Covers urban/green space coverage, pollution studies, illegal logging, forest fires, temperature studies, flooding, disaster response, and building footprints analysis.

title: 1  Week_1
text:
2.4 Summary
The field of remote sensing is essential for understanding and managing environmental hazards, especially in the context of urban sustainability and climate change. The module provides comprehensive training in using remote sensing data and tools for environmental analysis and decision-making.

title: 4  Week_3
text:
4.1 Notebook

4.1.1 Overview
Week 3 focuses on the critical aspects of remote sensing data, including corrections, data joining, and enhancement techniques, providing insights into practical applications and methodologies for processing and improving remote sensing imagery.


4.1.2 Key Concepts and Techniques

Remote Sensing Corrections: Essential for removing flaws due to sensor errors, atmospheric conditions, and terrain effects. Key correction types include:

Geometric Correction: Adjusts for distortions due to the satellite’s view angle, Earth’s rotation, and topography.
Atmospheric Correction: Removes atmospheric effects to improve image clarity and accuracy, crucial for applications requiring precise biophysical parameters.
Radiometric Calibration: Converts digital numbers (DN) to meaningful spectral radiance values, enabling comparison across different sensors and times.

Data Joining and Enhancement: Techniques to merge and enhance remote sensing data for clearer, more accurate representations.

Mosaicking and Feathering: Combining multiple images seamlessly, often used to create comprehensive maps from satellite data.
Contrast Enhancement: Adjusting image contrast to highlight features more distinctly.
Image Enhancement Techniques: Including band ratioing, filtering, and principal component analysis (PCA) to highlight specific aspects of the imagery.




4.1.3 Practical Insights

Virginia Norwood’s Contribution: The lecture highlights the pioneering work of Virginia Norwood in developing the multispectral scanner for Landsat, setting the foundation for modern remote sensing.
Sensor Technologies: Discussion on “push broom” and “whisk broom” sensors, illustrating the evolution and capabilities of satellite imaging technology.









Correcting Image Distortions: Detailed explanations on correcting geometric distortions using Ground Control Points (GCPs) and algorithms to align images accurately with geographic features.
Atmospheric Correction Methods: Explores various techniques, from simple Dark Object Subtraction (DOS) to advanced radiative transfer models, for removing atmospheric effects from imagery.
Enhancing Image Quality: Techniques like contrast stretching, filtering, and PCA are discussed for improving image quality and revealing hidden patterns in data.



4.1.4 Applications and Implications

Urban and Environmental Analysis: The lecture emphasizes the application of corrected and enhanced remote sensing data in urban planning, environmental monitoring, and disaster management.





Houston Harbour, Texas, with and without sun glint contamination (Vanhellemont, 2019)




Challenges in Data Processing: Discusses the complexities involved in pre-processing remotely sensed data, including the need for accurate correction and the potential pitfalls in data interpretation.
Future Directions: Encourages critical thinking about the use of remote sensing data in research and policy-making, highlighting the importance of understanding the underlying processes of data correction and enhancement.



4.1.5 Texture-Analysis
Definition and Importance

Texture analysis in remote sensing refers to the process of quantifying surface variations and patterns within an image, enhancing the understanding and interpretation of spatial distributions and relationships of pixels.
It is crucial for distinguishing features based on surface characteristics, beyond spectral signatures, enabling more accurate land cover classification, urban planning, and environmental monitoring.

Techniques and Measures

Gray-Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM): A statistical method that analyzes the frequency of pixel pairs at specific spatial relationships, offering insights into texture by calculating metrics like contrast, homogeneity, entropy, and correlation.
Fourier Transform: Analyzes the frequency components of an image to identify repetitive patterns, useful for identifying and classifying textural features in the landscape.

Conclusion

Texture analysis provides a valuable complement to spectral analysis in remote sensing, offering additional insights into the physical structure and variation of the Earth’s surface. It underscores the complexity and richness of remotely sensed data, advocating for a nuanced approach to data interpretation and application in various geographical and environmental studies.



4.1.6 Summary
This lecture provides a comprehensive overview of the techniques and challenges involved in processing remote sensing data. Through detailed explanations of correction methods, data joining techniques, and enhancements, students gain insights into the meticulous work required to transform raw satellite imagery into valuable information for a wide range of applications.

text: 6 Project Proposal - River Witham Ecological Enhancement Works Tender

title: 5  Week_4
text:
6.1 Introduction
We are pleased to submit our proposal for the River Witham Ecological Enhancement Works Tender. Our company is eager to take part in this important project and contribute to the ecological improvement of the River Witham in Grantham.

title: 5  Week_4
text:
6.2 Company Overview

6.2.1 Background
Oreooo is a reputable environmental services provider with a proven track record of successfully delivering similar projects. We are committed to sustainable practices and environmental conservation.


6.2.2 Expertise
Our team consists of highly skilled professionals with expertise in habitat restoration, river channel improvements, and ecological enhancements. We have successfully completed projects that align with the objectives outlined in the tender.

title: 5  Week_4
text:
6.3 Proposed Approach

6.3.1 Lot 1: River Witham Ecological Enhancement
Objective: To enhance the ecological value along the River Witham at Stonebridge Close and Sedgwick Meadows, Grantham.
Proposed Works:

Creation of berms
Installation of coir rolls
Installation of woody deflectors
Introduction of gravel
Berm repair and planting
Volunteer engagement



6.3.2 Lot 2: Environmental Improvements and Increased Accessibility
Objective: To enhance the ecological value along the River Witham through floodplain reconnection at Belton Parkland, Grantham.
Proposed Works:

Tree hinging
Bank lowering
Installation of in-channel woody materials
Placement of floodplain woody materials
Creation of beaver dam analogues using posts and faggots
Scrape creation

title: 5  Week_4
text:
6.4 Project Process










6.4.1 Step 1: Project Initiation (6 weeks)

6.4.1.1 Week 1-2: Project Inception and Team Formation

Define project requirements and objectives
Appoint a project manager and team members
Identify key success factors for the project



6.4.1.2 Week 3-4: Preparation of Project Documents and Contract Agreements

Develop project plan and Work Breakdown Structure (WBS)
Prepare tender documents and contract drafts
Review contract details, including schedules and milestones



6.4.1.3 Week 5-6: Tender Announcement and Supplier Registration

Publish tender announcement
Accept registration applications from potential suppliers
Prepare supplier information packages




6.4.2 Step 2: Supplier Evaluation and Selection (8 weeks)

6.4.2.1 Week 7-8: Tender Submission and Evaluation

Collect supplier bids
Evaluate bids, including technical and financial assessments
Identify qualified suppliers who meet the criteria




6.4.3 Step 3: Project Execution (12 months)

6.4.3.1 Month 1-2: Contractor Preparation and Material Procurement

Finalize the selection of the supplier
Contractor prepares a work plan and allocates resources
Commence material procurement and equipment setup



6.4.3.2 Month 3-6: Engineering Construction

Contractor carries out River Witham habitat improvement works
Monitor progress of the construction and ensure quality control



6.4.3.3 Month 7-9: Volunteer Engagement (if applicable)

Conduct volunteer training and recruitment
Assist volunteers in participating in ecological improvement projects



6.4.3.4 Month 10-12: Project Completion and Acceptance

Complete the construction work
Conduct final acceptance and quality review
Prepare project reports and documentation




6.4.4 Step 4: Project Delivery and Acceptance (4 weeks)

6.4.4.1 Week 1-2: Final Acceptance and Document Submission

Conduct final acceptance of the project results
Submit project reports and documentation
Organize project documents to meet audit requirements



6.4.4.2 Week 3-4: Project Acceptance and Settlement

Complete project acceptance procedures
Final settlement and payment to the supplier
Complete project closure and archive documentation

We will employ a dedicated project manager to oversee all project activities, coordinate with subcontractors, ensure quality control, and adhere to the project schedule. We will use Gantt charts to monitor and manage project progress effectively.

title: 5  Week_4
text:

Our proposal aligns with the objectives of enhancing the ecological value of the River Witham in Grantham, as outlined in the tender. We are committed to delivering high-quality work that meets the European Structural Investment Fund’s funding requirements, contributes to sustainable development goals, and addresses the environmental improvement needs of the region.

title: 5  Week_4
text:
6.8 Notebook

6.8.1 LULC
LULC stands for Land Use and Land Cover. It refers to the classification of the Earth’s surface into different categories based on how the land is used by humans (such as residential, agricultural, industrial) and the natural cover present on the land (like forests, water bodies, deserts).


6.8.2 SAR(Synthetic Aperture Radar)

High-resolution radar system.
Mounted on aircraft or satellites.
Uses microwave signals, receives reflections.
Functions in all weather, day and night.
Applications: terrain mapping, environmental monitoring, agriculture, forestry, urban planning, disaster assessment.
Penetrates vegetation, some surface materials.
Provides in-depth ground information, complementing optical satellites.



6.8.3 SAR polarization

Single = 1 horizontal (or vertical)
Dual = transmits and receives both horizontal and vertical
HH = emitted in horizontal (H) and received in horizontal (H)

title: 5  Week_4
text:
6.9 
纽约市：宜居的气候，气候变暖对高原植被的影响
通过遥感来检测监测气候变化，全球目标C40,
新加坡热环境，2050年实现0碳 green plan，它相应了
方法：增加绿地面积，改变建筑布局（减少空调使用）——城市规划解决热效应
局部气候问题，城市形态+建成环境landcover（分类）
连续变量，没有必要做这个植被分类变量，单纯分析他们的相关关系
我们可以做的：通过遥感计算热环境的公式，存在这个变量；LCC和热岛之间的关系
optional：urban fall和经济效应联合起来，会不会对热岛效应的研究有变化
ps：提出假设（比如高层建筑影响热环境），做出分析，拿着结果去找政策对应，一切研究最终要回归政策，最终呈现的结果要很简单（高层建筑会影响热环境，且响应了政策的某部分（作为reference）
海岸线侵蚀，植被，预测
关键词：urban island；
竞标：做的东西简单——结果又要有效

title: 8  Week_7
text: 9 Week_7 Google Earth Engine

title: 8  Week_7
text:
9.1 Introduction
“Geospatial” processing service, which permits geospatial analysis at scale. Where scale means massive datasets, planetary sclae analysis and fast. GEE stores data on servers so that it can be used to make queryable online applications. Literally, anything that has ee in front of it is stored on the server, which termed “proxy objects”. In addition, techniques for loading and filtering image collections, geometries, and features are covered. Methods for reducing images (including zonal statistics), applying regression over time, and using joins to combine datasets are explored.
centered, scale, region

9.1.1 Practical
PCA is a statistical method used to reduce the dimensionality of the data while retaining the most variability.

PCA in GEE: PCA is usually performed in GEE to reduce the dimensionality of remote sensing data and to highlight key information about land cover, change detection, or other environmental features.
PCA in R: Compared with GEE, the data processing capability of R is limited by local computing resources. While R can handle big data, dealing with particularly large data sets may require optimizing code or using specific packages such as bigmemory or ff to manage memory usage.
Although PCA in GEE and R are used for data reduction and feature extraction, GEE is more suitable for processing large-scale remote sensing image data and geospatial analysis, while R provides more flexible data processing and statistical analysis tools, which are suitable for various types of data.



9.1.2 Feedback
